=== Changes to customs based on Confucianism === Under Confucianism the typical family was [[patriarchy|patriarchal]] because men had the capability to pass on the family name and carry on the [[Kinship|lineage]] of the [[ancestors]]; women were expected to be subservient.<ref name="Yao4" /> Adoption of Western family values in the twentieth century challenged traditional Chinese values.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese vs. Western Perspectives|last=Zhou|first=Jinghao|publisher=Lexington Books|year=2013|isbn=9780739180457|location=|pages=33|quote=|via=}}</ref> [[Chinese nationalism|Nationalism]] contributed to the changes of customs and status of women.<ref>{{Cite book|title=East Asia: A Cultural, Social, and Political History|last=Ebrey|first=|last2=Walthall|last3=Palais|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|year=2009|isbn=978-0-547-00534-8|location=|pages=414–15|quote=|via=}}</ref> Nationalist revolutionary [[Qiu Jin]] promoted feminism through various essays and speeches, as well as through her ''Chinese Women's Journal''.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=East Asia: A Cultural, Social, and Political History|last=Ebrey|first=|last2=Walthall|last3=Palais|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|year=2009|isbn=978-0-547-00534-8|location=|pages=413|quote=|via=}}</ref> Jin chastised wife beating, female infanticide, arranged marriages, and foot binding.<ref name=":0" /> She eventually began teaching at a girls' school.<ref name=":0" /> Around this time, many other schools for girls opened in China.<ref name=":0" /> This led to increased job opportunities for women in the 1920s.<ref>{{Cite book|title=East Asia: A Cultural, Social, and Political History|last=Ebrey|first=|last2=Walthall|last3=Palais|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|year=2009|isbn=978-0-547-00534-8|location=|pages=413–14|quote=|via=}}</ref>
Later, as the Communist regime changed the structure of Chinese society through economic reform, the structure of the Chinese family was altered.<ref name="Guthrie">Guthrie, Doug. (2008). "China and Globalization: The Social, Economic and Political Transformation of Chinese Society". pp. 77- 86. London: Taylor & Francis.</ref> "The Four Olds" (''sijiu'') – old ideas, old habits, old customs, old cultures – were discouraged and were replaced by Communist ideology, particularly during the Cultural Revolution.<ref name="Guthrie" /> The economy was shifted to total government control with few chances to own private property and communal property.<ref>{{Cite book|title=East Asia: A Cultural, Social, and Political History|last=Patricia Ebrey, Anne Walthall, and James Palais|first=|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company|year=2009|isbn=9780547005348|location=Boston and New York|pages=461|quote=|via=}}</ref> [[Collectivization]] destroyed "clan-based" systems and had a great effect on motivation of workers and family loyalties.<ref name="Guthrie" />
The traditional social structure was further degraded by the [[Cultural Revolution]].<ref name="Guthrie" /> The [[Red Guards (China)|Red Guards]] turned members of a family against one another as they sought out "class enemies" to be sent for "re-education," ultimately resulting in a loss of family ties.<ref name="Guthrie" /> Women were elevated to equal status as men through a series of laws which prohibited practices such as arranged marriages, [[concubinage]]s, [[dowry|dowries]], and [[child marriage|child betrothals]].<ref name="Guthrie" /> Under these marriage laws, women enjoyed joint property in marriage and could file for a divorce.<ref name="Guthrie" />
As a result of Communist rule in China, the social status of women improved greatly.<ref name="Communism">Hayes, Jeff (2008). "Women Under Communism", Facts and Details:China, Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from http://factsanddetails.com/china.php?itemid=105&catid=4&subcatid=21#02 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091127050507/http://factsanddetails.com/china.php?itemid=105&catid=4&subcatid=21 |date=2009-11-27 }}</ref> Women were empowered to work outside the home.<ref name="Communism" /> Communist rule also brought about the end of practices such as foot binding, child marriages, [[prostitution]], and [[arranged marriage]]s.<ref name="Communism" /> China has seen a decrease in [[domestic violence]] due to government-supported grassroots programs to counter these practices.<ref name="FactsAndDetails.com">Hayes, Jeff (2008). "Women in China" Facts and Details: China, Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from {{cite web |url=http://factsanddetails.com/china.php?itemid=105&catid=4&subcatid=21 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091127050507/http://factsanddetails.com/china.php?itemid=105&catid=4&subcatid=21 |archivedate=2009-11-27 |df= }}</ref> Women in rural areas remain largely uneducated.<ref name="Village Women">Hayes, Jeff (2008). "Village Women" Facts and Details: China. Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from http://factsanddetails.com/china.php?itemid=105&catid=4&subcatid=21#02 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091127050507/http://factsanddetails.com/china.php?itemid=105&catid=4&subcatid=21 |date=2009-11-27 }}</ref>
=== Population control === During the reform period, the Communist regime in China regulated [[birth control]].<ref name="Guthrie" /> The government shaped policies with the intention to develop population science “through selective absorption of Western science and technology.”<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Women In China's Long Twentieth Century|last=Hershatter|first=Gail|publisher=University of California Press|year=2007|isbn=978-0-520-09856-5|location=Berkeley, Los Angeles, and London|pages=27|quote=|via=}}</ref> In 1979, the [[Family planning policy|Planned Birth Policy]] was implemented.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Birth Control in China 1949–2000 : Population Policy and Demographic Development|last=Scharping|first=Thomas|publisher=Taylor and Francis|year=2013|isbn=978-0-7007-1154-3|location=|pages=4|quote=|via=}}</ref> The Chinese government only allowed one child per Han family, with more children allowed to non-Han families.<ref name=":3" /> Since this planned birth policy was implemented based on local laws rather than on a national population law, the level of birth restriction differed in urban and rural areas.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Women In China's Long Twentieth Century|last=Hershatter|first=Gail|publisher=University of California Press|year=2007|isbn=978-0-520-09856-5|location=Berkeley, Los Angeles, and London|pages=27–28|quote=|via=}}</ref> In families reliant on farming for income, the household is the fundamental unit of production, so many rural families would rather pay the hefty fines for excess birth.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Women In China's Long Twentieth Century|last=Hershatter|first=Gail|publisher=University of California Press|year=2007|isbn=978-0-520-09856-5|location=Berkeley, Los Angeles, and London|pages=28|quote=|via=}}</ref>
In 2011, city couples who both came from one-child families were allowed to have a second child, while couples in rural areas could have a second if just one of them came from a one-child family.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/doc/nb/news/14956C3C5EFFAF28?p=AWNB|title=Shanghai Municipal Government: Young Couples Sticking with One Child|last=|first=|date=November 16, 2011|work=China Business News (China)|access-date=November 20, 2016|via=}}</ref> In 2013, the further revision of the Planned Birth Policy allowed couples in which either parent had no siblings to have two children.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/doc/nb/news/14B0B267AD5D1D08?p=AWNB|title=Child policy eased, camp abolished|last=|first=|date=December 29, 2013|work=Shanghai Daily (China)|access-date=November 20, 2016|via=}}</ref> In 2015, China allowed all couples to have two children, abolishing its decades-long one-child policy for urban families.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/doc/nb/news/158CAF6871392A70?p=AWNB|title=One-Child Policy Lifted, All Couples Allowed Two Children|last=Xin, Lin and Gang, Wu|first=|date=October 30, 2015|work=Global Times (Beijing, China)|access-date=November 20, 2016|via=}}</ref>
Another instance of population control is the prevalence of [[female infanticide]].<ref name="Guthrie" /> People in rural areas practiced female infanticide and selective neglect due to a preference of sons over daughters.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Women In China's Long Twentieth Century|last=Hershatter|first=Gail|publisher=University of California Press|year=2007|isbn=9780520098565|location=Berkeley, Los Angeles, and London|pages=28–29|quote=|via=}}</ref> Since the 1980s, roughly 200,000 female infants would be killed per year because of the preference for male children and the advancement in technologies such as [[ultrasound]], which help to find out the sex of the fetus.<ref name="Guthrie" /> In addition to female infanticide, girls are being unregistered or are abandoned by their families, which stops them from receiving education and legal benefits the government offered.<ref name="Guthrie" /> These methods of controlling population have resulted in a huge [[china gender gap|gender gap]] in China.<ref name="Guthrie" />
== Chinese women throughout the workplace ==
=== History of working women === [[File:Rice fields mazandaran.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Women working in [[Paddy field|rice fields]]]]
In the imperial era, women experienced physical restrictions that limited their social positions.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=29|quote=|via=}}</ref> They held jobs that required minimal physical activity like domestic chores and producing textiles to sell or use.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=167–169|quote=|via=}}</ref>
During [[History of the People's Republic of China (1949–1976)|Mao's rule]] (1949–1976), Chinese women were needed for their manual labor for farming and for urban industrialization.<ref name=":6" /> To compensate for their hard work, they were provided access to education and politics.<ref name="Chinese Feminism Faces Globalization">Perry, Susan H. Chinese Feminism Faces Globalization. Retrieved 2 Nov 2009. Retrieved from https://www.questia.com/googleScholar.qst;jsessionid=KwTGhzy305KmJZ25jjkRgHQ1TmFh1gPnhzZGTyCZpv6czQ1GMLf6!101686917!1275526282?docId=5002557820.</ref> The Chinese government supported women's education.<ref name="Yao 1983 174">{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=174|quote=|via=}}</ref> The percentage of girls attending school was 96.2% compared to below 20% before the [[People's Republic of China|People's Republic]] (1949).<ref name="Chinese Women" /> The Chinese government has tried to decrease the number of women illiterates while promoting adult and vocational schools.<ref name="Yao 1983 174"/> The percentage number of illiterates has gone down from 90% in 1949 and 32% from 1993.<ref name="Chinese Women">China Daily. "Chinese Women".Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from {{cite web |url=http://www.chinaculture.org/gb/en_aboutchina/2003-09/24/content_24139.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-07-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923221936/http://www.chinaculture.org/gb/en_aboutchina/2003-09/24/content_24139.htm |archivedate=2015-09-23 |df= }}.</ref> In the first 30 years of Communist rule women's discrimination was decreasing, but they did not have jobs that had real decision-making power.<ref name="Chinese Feminism Faces Globalization" /><ref name="Working Women in China">Hayes, Jeff (2008). "Working Women in China-Facts and Details". Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from http://factsanddetails.com/china.</ref>
The Chinese government has made great efforts to achieve a high level of economic status for women.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=165–173|quote=|via=}}</ref> Since 1949, with the founding of the People' Republic, the rate for employed women has risen.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=170|quote=|via=}}</ref> Chinese women account for 44% of the work force and 34.5% account for the women's work force in the world.<ref name="Chinese Women" />
=== Rural areas === The key role women have in farming is to maintain ownership of the main sources of production in rural areas.<ref name="Woman-Work115">Davin, Delia (1976). ''Woman-Work: Women and the Party in Revolutionary China.'' p. 115. Oxford: Clarendon.</ref> In traditional China, women were not allowed to own land or property.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=23|quote=|via=}}</ref> Land was inherited through the sons, and if there was no son in the family, it was taken by a close male relative.<ref name="Woman-Work116">Davin, Delia (1976). ''Woman-Work: Women and the Party in Revolutionary China.'' p. 116. Oxford: Clarendon.</ref> In less populated areas, women do more agricultural work than men because of [[shifting cultivation]].<ref name="Woman-Work119" /> In more populated areas, men do more work than women because extensive [[plough]] cultivation is used.<ref name="Women's Role in Economic Development">Boserup, Ester (1970). ''Women's Role in Economic Development'' p. 35. London: Allen and Unwin.</ref> Female involvement is high in the [[Multiple cropping|double-cropping]] rice area.<ref name="Woman-Work119">Davin, Delia (1976). ''Woman-Work: Women and the Party in Revolutionary China.'' p. 119. Oxford: Clarendon.</ref> Other types of work women perform in the countryside include pig and poultry rearing, [[Spinning (textiles)|spinning]], [[weaving]], [[Basket weaving|basket-making]], and other handicrafts. This type of work supplements agricultural income.<ref name="Woman-Work120">Davin, Delia (1976). ''Woman-Work: Women and the Party in Revolutionary China.'' p. 120. Oxford: Clarendon.</ref> [[File:Professional woman.jpg|thumb|299x299px| A professional woman is making a deal with her male client. This shows globalization has increased job opportunities for women in urban China. ]]
=== Urban areas === China's economic policies laid the basis of the [[industrialization]] drive in export-oriented development, and its reliance on low-wage [[manufacturing]] to produce consumer goods for the world market.<ref name="Gender and Change">Lee, Eliza W.Y. (2003). ''Gender and Change in Hong Kong: Globalization, Postcolonialism, and Chinese Patriarchy''.pp. 1-224. UBC Press,{{ISBN|0-7748-0994-9}}, {{ISBN|978-0-7748-0994-8}}</ref> Young [[immigrant|migrant]] women left their homes in rural settings to work in urban industrial areas.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Out to Work|last=Gaetano|first=Arianne M.|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press|year=2015|isbn=9780824840990|location=Honolulu|pages=1–6|quote=|via=}}</ref> Work included [[export-oriented industrialization]], manufacturing in electronics and toy assembly, sewing in garment production, and mixed assembly and sewing in the footwear industry.<ref name=":5" /> [[Hong Kong]] and [[Shenzhen]] were cities established as centers of export-oriented industrialization, and migrant women workers have made up 70% of Shenzhen's three million people.<ref name="Gender and Change" />
Private sector employers are reluctant to hire women because Chinese law requires that the employer cover maternity leave and childbirth costs.<ref>Tatlow, Didi Kirsten. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/26/world/asia/26iht-china.html?partner=rss&emc=rss "For China's Women, More Opportunities, More Pitfalls."] ''[[nytimes.com]]'', 25 November 2010</ref> However, certain industries prefer female workers for assumed benefits.<ref name=":7" /> For example, the beauty economy, which is defined as "a marketplace in which young, attractive women are used to promote commercial products and services," includes the sales industry.<ref name=":7">Osburg, John (2013). "Anxious Wealth: Money and Morality among China's New Rich", p. 144. Stanford University Press, Stanford. {{ISBN|978-0-8047-8354-5}}</ref> The development of the sales industry has increased job opportunities for women, but women are also restricted to these gendered professions.<ref>Osburg, John (2013). "Anxious Wealth: Money and Morality among China's New Rich", p. 143-182. Stanford University Press, Stanford. {{ISBN|978-0-8047-8354-5}}</ref>
==== Reasons for migrant labor ==== [[File:Seagate Wuxi China Factory Tour.jpg|thumb|180px|Workers perform final testing and [[Quality assurance|QA]] before sending [[Disk storage|drives]] off to customers on its 2.5-inch [[Laptop|notebook]] lines.|left]] A recent phenomenon, the migration of rural Chinese workers began in 1984 when the Regulations of Permanent Residence Registration became less punitive and allowed people to move to find employment.<ref name="Female Migrant">China-Labour. "'Dagongmei' – Female Migrant Labourers." pp. 1-8. Retrieved 5 November 2009. Retrieved from {{cite web |url=http://www.china-labour.org.hk/en |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091027112136/http://www.china-labour.org.hk/en/ |archivedate=2009-10-27 |df= }}</ref> People left rural areas to escape poverty, and females left due to the lack of local opportunities for women.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Out to Work|last=Gaetano|first=Arianna M.|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press|year=2015|isbn=9780824840990|location=Honolulu|pages=36|quote=|via=}}</ref> In the cities, women could find new, low-paid factory-based jobs that did not require highly skilled workers.<ref name=":5" /> According to national statistics, the ratio of male to female migrant workers averages 2:1, and an estimated 30-40 million of the migrant women work in the cities, namely Hong Kong and Shenzhen.<ref name="Female Migrant" />
In the Nanshan district of Shenzhen, females comprised 80% of the workforce and had an average age of 23.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> Young female workers are preferred over older females or males for several reasons.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> First, as married women are less mobile, female migrant workers are younger and more likely to be single than their male counterparts.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> Young rural women are preferred for these jobs primarily because they are less likely to get pregnant, and are able and willing to withstand longer working hours, have "nimble fingers, and will be less experienced in asking for their [[Statutory law|statutory rights]].<ref name="Female Migrant" /> In many cases, migrant women sign contracts stating that they will not get pregnant within their period of employment."<ref name="Female Migrant" />
In the interest of the family, rural females are sent to find urban employment over male counterparts, mainly to supplement familial income at home and to support the males, who are more likely to attend college.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> The male standard of education in China is higher, particularly when a family is under financial stress, females are more likely to drop out of school to generate income for the family.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Gender Inequality in Education in China: A Meta-Regression Analysis|journal=Contemporary Economic Policy|volume=32}}</ref> Because females have lesser impact on the family's long-term financial stability, their rights for opportunities development are consequently unequal.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> This inequality also reinforces emotional motivations for migration.<ref>Gaetano, A.M. (2015). "Out to Work", p. 8. University of Hawai'i Press, Honolulu. {{ISBN|978-0-8248-4098-3}}</ref> Many women migrate to find personal fulfillment.<ref>Poras, M. (Director). (2013). ''The Mosuo Sisters'' [Video file] In The Mosuo Sisters. Retrieved October, 2016.</ref> Stereotypes in China that developed as a result of globalization portray rural women as "‘backward’" and urban women as "‘modern’".<ref>Gaetano, A.M. (2015). "Out to Work", p. 31. University of Hawai'i Press, Honolulu. {{ISBN|978-0-8248-4098-3}}</ref> Many people associate modernity with maturity, so rural women migrate to cities to be perceived as mature.<ref>Gaetano, A.M. (2015). "Out to Work", p. 3. University of Hawai'i Press, Honolulu. {{ISBN|978-0-8248-4098-3}}</ref> Migrant women also appreciate the knowledge they obtain (including political- and self-awareness) while living in cities.<ref>Gaetano, A.M. (2015). "Out to Work", p. 80. University of Hawai'i Press, Honolulu. {{ISBN|978-0-8248-4098-3}}</ref> Some women even report desiring to leave villages as a result of boredom with rural life.<ref>Gaetano, A.M. (2015). "Out to Work", p. 40. University of Hawai'i Press, Honolulu. {{ISBN|978-0-8248-4098-3}}</ref> Ideas perpetuated due to globalization simultaneously increased women's intentions to become independent; many migrant workers desire lives separate from those of their families’.<ref>Gaetano, A.M. (2015). "Out to Work", p. 30. University of Hawai'i Press, Honolulu. {{ISBN|978-0-8248-4098-3}}</ref>
This new system allowed rural residents to migrate, it did not allow them to change their residence or accept any [[Social welfare|benefits]] in the cities.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title=Made in China|last=Pun|first=Ngai|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|year=2005|isbn=9780822386759|location=Hong Kong|pages=115|quote=|via=}}</ref> This resulted in a growing population of migrant laborers without the minimal benefits of residency including medical care, housing, or education.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> Many migrant women do not trust the government to protect their rights.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Out to Work|last=Gaetano|first=Arianne M.|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press|year=2015|isbn=978-0-8248-4098-3|location=Honolulu, Hawai'i|pages=64|quote=|via=}}</ref> Today, up to 90% of migrants work without contracts, in violation of the [[Chinese labour law]].<ref name="Female Migrant" />
==== Degradation ==== The freedom to display femininity and gender equality seem incompatible in Chinese society.<ref name="Liu 2008 87–92">{{Cite book|title=East Asian Sexualities: Modernity, Gender, and New Sexual Cultures|last=Liu|first=Jieyu|publisher=Zed Books Ltd.|year=2008|isbn=9781842778883|location=London|pages=87–92|quote=|via=}}</ref> Gender equality appeared prevailing only when women were restricted to desexualization in the Mao era.<ref name="Liu 2008 87–92"/> [[Chinese economic reform|Opening up policy]] guarantees women's freedom for resexualization, but it simultaneously brings back gender inequality.<ref>{{Cite book|title=East Asian Sexualities: Modernity, Gender, and New Sexual Cultures|last=Jackson, Liu, and Woo|first=Stevi, Jieyu, and Juhyun|publisher=Zed Books Ltd|year=2008|isbn=978-1-84277-888-3|location=London and New York|pages=87|quote=|via=}}</ref>
Women factory workers are known as "''dagongmei''" (working girls).<ref>{{Cite book|title=Made In China: Women Factory Workers in a Global Workplace|last=Pun|first=Ngai|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|year=2005|isbn=9780822386759|location=Hong Kong|pages=2|quote=|via=}}</ref> They are traditionally young women migrants who experience a segmented [[labor market]] in informal and low-wage employment sectors.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Out To Work|last=Gaetano|first=Arianna M.|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press|year=2015|isbn=9780824840990|location=Honolulu|pages=60|quote=|via=}}</ref> Workers in export-oriented factories receive [[minimum wage]] and minimum [[overtime]] pay, they pay for meals and lodging at the factory, and they pay fines for breaking [[factory]] rules.<ref name=":5">''China Blue''. Dir. Micha X. Peled. Perf. Jasmine Li. 2005. Accessed Web. 20 Nov. 2016. https://www.pbs.org/independentlens/chinablue/film.html</ref> The average daily wage, for a 12-hour day in a toy factory, in the mid-1990s was $1.10 USD for migrant women workers in Shenzhen.<ref name="Gender and Change" /> Although migrant workers in China still earn low wages, their average income has increased over the past several years.<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=https://www.statista.com/statistics/306686/china-monthly-income-of-migrant-workers/|title=China: migrant workers average monthly income 2015 {{!}} Statistic|website=Statista|access-date=2016-11-22}}</ref> In 2008, the average daily income for migrant workers in China was equivalent to $6.48 USD.<ref name=":9" /> In 2014, the average daily income was equivalent to $13.86 USD.<ref name=":9" />
These conditions create "maximum [[Economic surplus|surplus]] appropriation"; workers' daily lives revolve around factory production and are dependent on the economic conditions.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chinese Women: Past and Present|last=Yao|first=Esther S. Lee|publisher=Ide House, Inc.|year=1983|isbn=0866630996|location=Mesquite, Texas|pages=166|quote=|via=}}</ref> The state disallows local [[unionization]] and has the [[All-China Federation of Trade Unions]] (ACFTU) as the legitimate forum of worker representation.<ref name="Gender and Change" /> Without the right to form [[Trade union|unions]] and with the state sanctioned ACFTU, migrant women workers find it hard to effectively gain suitable rights and treatment from the factory management.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> The 2003 statistics from the People's University show 90% of migrants work without contracts, directly violating the Chinese Labour Law.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> According to the ACFTU, migrant workers are owed over 100 billion Yuan in back wages.<ref name="Female Migrant" />
Organizations are now attempting to assist and empower female migrant workers through training and education on their labor-related rights.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Out to Work|last=Gaetano|first=Arianne M.|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press|year=2015|isbn=9780824840990|location=Honolulu|pages=5–6|quote=|via=}}</ref> Legal clinics have begun to assist female migrants in filing claims against employers and local labor bureaus.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> One case of female worker exploitation in the Hua Yi garment factory in [[Beijing]] resulted in mistreatment by management as well as withholding pay for at least 24 women.<ref name="Female Migrant" /> After filing complaints, in collaboration with the Center for Women's Law Studies and Legal Services of [[Beijing University]], the women received 170,000 Yuan in back wages and compensation.<ref name="Female Migrant" />
Relations between workers and employers represent both the immediate need of manufacturing plants for large quantities of low wage laborers, and the insecurities young workers face in relocating long distances to life in factory dormitories.<ref name=":5" /> Hiring single young women serve needs of [[management]].<ref name="Gender and Change" /> The employment of young females allow management to exhibit maximum control and authority over the [[labor force]].<ref name="Gender and Change" /> Compared to older women and male workers, young single women are susceptible to the authority and demands of management.<ref name="Gender and Change" /> The common manipulation of "factory as family" by owners and managers suggests how [[workers]] hold a subliminal status within the factory environment.<ref name="Gender and Change" /> Uneven power relations inside the factory result in demands from management for personal services from women workers, from hair washing to sex.<ref name="Gender and Change" />
== See also == * [[Women in China]] * [[Factory worker]] * [[Chinese family name]] * [[Chinese marriage]] * [[Culture of China]] * [[Communist Party of China]] * [[Sexuality in China]] * [[Chinese economic reforms]] * [[Economy of China]] * [[Hypergamy]] * [[Heteronormativity]] * [[Arranged marriage]] * [[Spring and Autumn period|Spring and Autumn Period]] * [[Qiu Jin]] * [[Chinese nationalism|Chinese Nationalism]] * [[Family planning policy]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{Economy of China}}
{{Good article}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Impact Of Globalization On Women In China}} <!--Categories--> [[Category:Chinese women]] [[Category:Social history of China]] [[Category:Women in China]] [[Category:Gender studies]] [[Category:Women's rights in Asia]] [[Category:Social change]] [[Category:Globalization by location|China]]

page.title: History of the Jews in Kosovo

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Jewish Yugoslav history to [[:Category:Jews and Judaism in Yugoslavia]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 5]].
revision.text:
[[File:Scripture in Jewish cemetery in Prishtina, Kosovo.JPG|thumb|Jewish tumbstone in Pristina]] [[File:Jewish cemetery in Prishtina, Kosovo with Prishtina on background.JPG|thumb|Jewish cemetery in Pristina]] The '''history of the [[Jewish]] community in [[Kosovo]]''' largely mirrors that of [[Serbia]], except during the [[Second World War]], when Kosovo, as part of Kingdom of Albania, was [[Albania under Italy|under Italian control]] and later [[Albania under Germany|under German control]]. The other exception is following the [[Kosovo War]] of 1999, when the province began its political separation from Serbia. == Ottoman rule == {{see also|History of the Jews in Turkey}} Prior to the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman Turkish]] conquest of the region, documentation on the Jews of the [[Balkans]] was sketchy. The Jewish communities of the Balkans were boosted in the 15th and 16th centuries by the arrival of Jewish refugees fleeing the [[Spanish Inquisition|Spanish]] and [[Portuguese Inquisition|Portuguese]] Inquisitions. [[Sultan]] [[Bayezid II]] of the [[Ottoman Empire]] welcomed the Jewish refugees into his empire. Jews became involved in trade between the various provinces in the Ottoman Empire, becoming especially important in the salt trade.[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/serbia.html Virtual Jewish History Tour - Serbia and Montenegro] The 1455 [[Ottoman Empire|Turkish]] [[cadastral tax census]]{{Ref|a|a}} of the [[House of Branković|Branković]] lands (covering 80% of present-day Kosovo) recorded 1 Jewish dwelling in [[Vučitrn]].
An [[Austria]]n statisticDetailbeschreibung des Sandzaks Plevlje und des Vilajets Kosovo (Mit 8 Beilagen und 10 Taffeln), Als Manuskript gedruckt, Vien 1899, 80-81 {{de icon}} published in 1899 estimated: * [[Albanians]]: (48%) * [[Serbs]]: (44%) * Remaining 8%: [[Tsintsars]], [[Turkish people|Turks]], [[Circassians]], [[Romani people|Romani]], and Jews
== Yugoslavian rule == In the aftermath of [[World War I]], [[Kingdom of Serbia|Serbia]] merged with [[Kingdom of Montenegro|Montenegro]], and then united with the [[State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs]] to form the [[Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes]], which was soon renamed [[History of The Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Kingdom of Yugoslavia]]. The largely Albanian-populated Kosovo was included within Serbia. At the time, some 500 Jews resided in Kosovo.{{cite book | last = Romano | first = Jasa | title = Jews of Yugoslavia 1941–1945 | publisher = Federation of Jewish Communities of Yugoslavia | year = 1980 | pages = 573–590}} The 1921 population [[census]] for the territories comprising modern-day Kosovo listed 439,010 inhabitants:
By [[religion]]: * [[Muslims]]: 329,502 (75%) * [[Serbian Orthodox Church|Serbian Orthodox]]: 93,203 * [[Roman Catholics]]: 15,785 * [[Jews]]: 427 * [[Greek Catholics]]: 26
== World War II and The Holocaust == In 1941, Kosovo was incorporated into the [[Albanian Kingdom (1939–1943)|Italian-ruled Greater Albania]], and the local Jewish population was protected from the [[Nazi]]-led [[Holocaust]]. In July 1943, when [[Italian surrender|Italy left the war]], the Germans took control of Kosovo and recruited the [[21st Waffen Mountain Division of the SS Skanderbeg (1st Albanian)|Skanderbeg Division]] of Albanian collaborators to defeat [[Yugoslav partisans]] and exterminate the Jews. In 1944, [[Yugoslav Partisans|communist partisans]] recaptured Kosovo from Albania and made it part of the [[Democratic Federal Yugoslavia]]. === Deportations and death / survival figures === '''Critical evaluation of all reference materials listed below should be skillfully employed to filter internal bias within the source.''' Current literature indicates four sets of numerically recorded deportations from Kosovo: 1) August 1941, Mitrovica, under German occupation, 88 Jews are reported to have been sent to [[Sajmište concentration camp|Sajmiste Concentration Camp]] near [[Axis occupation of Serbia|axis occupied]] Belgrade where they were killed. Prior to deportation all Jewish men in Mitrovica / Mitrovice are alleged to have been arrested, while women were sent to daily forced labor. In February 1942, the women are said to have been detained with their children, Jewish property taken by local collaborators, and Synagogue destroyed. A 1960 report to the Administration of the State Security of NR Serbia [http://kosovoholocaust.com/page4/page17/page17.html details names] of victims from 12 families shot at the camp in winter 1941.{{Cite web|url=http://kosovoholocaust.com/|title=Kosovo Holocaust|website=kosovoholocaust.com|access-date=2018-02-22}} [While source shows significant signs of bias in tone, second generational verbal accounts of deportations from Mitrovica can still be sourced today. Supplementary survivor testimony in the [https://sfi.usc.edu/vha Shoah Foundation Archive] also makes reference to experience of the holocaust in relation to movements through [[Mitrovica, Kosovo|Kosvoska Mitrovica]]] 2) 1942, Prishtina. 250 Yugoslav Jews, including an unknown number of native Kosovo Jews, transferred to the Albanian interior. As of 1943 historian Daniel Perez relates they made up part of 500 Jews held under house arrest or in concentration camps in the Albanian towns of Berat, Kruja and Kavaja. He also indicates movements of both native and non-native Jews from Kosovo to Albania were ongoing throughout the war period.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hW8pDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA25&lpg=PA25&dq=Daniel+Perez+kosovo+holocaust&source=bl&ots=PfT1bWe8ls&sig=IBo2H_jl677rPnGqD0sVksz---A&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjk_K6HvbXZAhWqKMAKHUZ9BLwQ6AEIRDAI#v=onepage&q=Daniel%20Perez%20kosovo%20holocaust&f=false|title=In, Bringing the Dark Past to Light: The Reception of the Holocaust in Postcommunist Europe|last=Perez|first=Daniel|last2=Edited by John-Paul Himka|first2=and Joanna Beata Michlic|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|year=2008|isbn=9780803225442|location=USA|pages=27, 28, 29|language=en}} 3) March 1942, Prishtina. Italian military police detained 51 Jewish refugees and passed them to the Nazis. According to historian Noel Malcom they were sent to [[Sajmište concentration camp|Sajmiste]]. Daniel Perez details that the deportation list was compiled by Italian authorities and local Albanian police and that they were first sent to a "concentration camp" [probable terminiological error] in Prishtina before being transferred to Mitrovica.'''Malcolm, Noel'''. ''Kosovo: A Short History''. New York: New York University Press, 1998, Pages 213, 231,310 {{ISBN|978-0330412247}} 4) May 14, 1944, Prishtina. [[21st Waffen Mountain Division of the SS Skanderbeg|Skanderburg Unit]] arrested 281Jews who were sent to [[Bergen-Belsen concentration camp|Bergen-Belsen]] via occupied Belgrade where, according to Noel Malcom, 'more than' 200 died, or according to Martin Cüppers, 'at least' 177 died.Martin Cüppers, “Mission in 'Greater Albania': The 21st Weapon Mountain Division of the ss 'Skanderbeg'” (paper presented at conference in Tirana, 19–20 May 2008{{Cite book|title=Albania at War, 1939-1945|last=Jürgen Fischer|first=Bernd|publisher=C. Hurst & Co. Publishers|year=1999|isbn=|location=Albania|pages=187}} Though the majority of historians seem to draw consensus around the 281 figure Albanian historian Haxhi Bajraktari is said to have written that only 43 Jewish names were included in a total of 249 deportees, whom he describes as mainly Communists and Partisans.''Marrëdhënjet Shqiptaro-Hebraike'', Instituti Shqiptar i Studimeve Politike, Tiranë, printed in Prishtinë in Albanian in 2009 Analysis of apparently [http://kosovoholocaust.com/page1/page1.html original Nazi transport lists] (as yet unverified by this author) suggest Bajraktari's apparent figures for Jews to be understated. Serbian historian Pavle Dzeletovic Ivanov also puts the number of arrests on May 14 at 400 (which conversely suggests overstatement).{{Cite book|title=Jevreji Kosova i Metohije|last=Dzeletovic Ivanov|first=Pavle|publisher=PANPUBLIK BEOGRAD|year=1988|isbn=|location=Belgrade|pages=70}} The names of those who both survived and perished at Bergen-Belsen are recorded at source [[Noel Malcolm|Noel Malcom]] summarises that out of 551 native Kosovo Jews present before war, 210 had died by the end. [Non-correspondence with the preliminary evidence above as incidents 1 and 4; (210 + 88) = approx 298. This could be because Malcom may not have come across, considered or rejected the Mitrovica deportations]. Video interviews with Kosovo Jews who survived the Holocaust can be found at the [[Shoah foundation|Shoah Foundation]]. === Extracts from witness statements === An extract from the statement of Hedviga Schönfein, prisoner of the Judenlager Zemlin (Sajmište) prison camp has been published by the Centre for Democracy and Reconciliation in South East Europe: "Immediately upon our arrival at the camp, the Germans told us that the camp would gradually be evacuated, because they intended to imprison communists at the Fair, but they did not want to tell us where they were going to take us.… For the first transfers they invited volunteers and the first to be invited was the group I was from – Jews from Kosmet. (…) Those who were designated for transport were ordered, or, more precisely, kindly advised to take their most valuable possessions with them, and to pack all the rest carefully and put their exact address on the package. (…) Thus, these transfers departed almost every day. On Sundays and holidays there were usually no transfers or removals, but there were days when the car would make two rounds. The driver of the grey car often entered the camp alone, gathered children around him, caressed them, took them in his arms and gave them candies. The children liked him and whenever he came, they would rush toward him to get candies. No one in the camp suspected that people were taken to their deaths. It was strongly believed they were being transferred into a work camp." {{Cite web|url=http://www.pollitecon.com/html/ebooks/Workbook-4-The-Second-World-War.pdf|title=Alternative Educational Materials. The Second World War, second edition. Centre for Democracy and Reconciliation in South East Europe.|last=Edited by Erdelja|first=Kresimir|date=|website=|access-date=2018-02-22}} A [http://kosovoholocaust.com/page56/page56.html statement] from Albert Ruben suggests a deportation from Prishtina in winter 1943, not recorded by the academic historians above: "At the end of 1943, it was already winter, maybe November or December, the SS men came to all Jewish homes to round us up. They got us out of our beds and took us straight to the barracks near the football field. There were a lot of us, more than four hundred people. We stayed there for two days. Everyone brought some food with them. We didn't have a toilet, so we dug a hole and put some wooden boards over it. They were threatening us, telling us to hand over our gold and other valuables, and we were throwing them into the toilet. What we had not given to the poor earlier we were now throwing into the toilet. Before long they put us into cattle wagons and drove us to the Belgrade camp for Jews at the Sajmiste." === Further sources of information on WWII and Holocaust period === Extensive information on the [[World War II in Albania|German occupation of Albania]] proper, with original Nazi source materials referring to Kosovo, can be found in the work of [[Robert Elsie|Robert Elise]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.albanianhistory.net/1945_German-Wehrmacht/index.html|title=1945 {{!}} Final Report of the German Wehrmacht in Albania|last=Elsie|first=Dr. Robert|website=www.albanianhistory.net|access-date=2018-02-20}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.albanianhistory.net/1956_Neubacher/index.html|title=1956 {{!}} Hermann Neubacher: A Nazi Diplomat on Mission in Albania|last=Elsie|first=Dr. Robert|website=www.albanianhistory.net|access-date=2018-02-20}} A thorough critique of the teaching of the subject of WWII and the holocaust in Kosovo schools has been produced by [http://oralhistorykosovo.org/research/the-second-wold-war/ Oral History Kosovo.] == Post-war community == The [[Federation of Jewish Communities in Yugoslavia]] was formed in the aftermath of [[World War II]] to coordinate the Jewish communities of post-war [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] and to lobby for the right of Jews to [[aliyah|immigrate to Israel]].[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/Yugoslavia2.html Jews of the Former Yugoslavia After the Holocaust] The Federation was headquartered in [[Belgrade]], the capital of the post-war Yugoslavia. More than half of the surviving Yugoslav Jews chose to immigrate to [[Israel]] after World War II. The Jewish community of [[Socialist Republic of Serbia|Serbia]], and indeed of all constituent republics in [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]], was maintained by the unifying power of the Federation of Jewish Communities in Yugoslavia. However, this power ended with the [[dissolution of Yugoslavia]] in the 1990s. == Yugoslav wars == The Jews of Serbia lived relatively peacefully in Yugoslavia between World War II and the 1990s. According to the 1991 census, there were 112 Jews in Kosovo, though it is possible that there have been more. However, the end of the [[Cold War]] saw the [[breakup of Yugoslavia]], and wars in [[Croatian War of Independence|Croatia]] and [[Bosnian War|Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. The war for Kosovo began in the 1990s, when Serbian leader [[Slobodan Milošević]] began consolidating power in Kosovo and the [[Kosovo Liberation Army]] waged a separatist insurgency. In 1999, international forces expelled Serb forces from Kosovo. During the conflict, the 50 remaining Jews in the capital city of [[Pristina]] fled to Serbia, with which they had close cultural and linguistic ties. == Post-war Kosovo == Currently there are very few Jews in Kosovo, according to Čeda Prlinčević, the leader of Pristina's small Jewish community. The lone Jewish community in [[Prizren]] speaks Albanian and Turkish, and has remained for the time being.{{cite news | last = Spritzer | first = Dina | title = Independence at a time of uncertainty for Kosovo's Jews | publisher = Jewish Telegraphic Agency | date = 2008-02-17 | url = http://www.jta.org/cgi-bin/iowa/news/article/2008021720080215kosovo.html}} This community numbers around 50 members, divided among three families. There are no Jewish schools. Unemployment is prevalent, and support for the community comes from the [[American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee]]. There has been some amount of intermarriage with the surrounding Albanian community. The father of Votim Demiri, Prizren's Jewish community leader, is Albanian.{{cite news | last = Jordan | first = Michael J. | title = Jews in Kosovo city share fate and struggle of Albanians | publisher = Jewish Telegraphic Agency | date = 1999-12-03 | url = http://www.jewishsf.com/content/2-0-/module/displaystory/story_id/12633/edition_id/243/format/html/displaystory.html}} Israel has good relations with the Kosovars, with the Israeli government sending massive humanitarian aid during and after the 1998-99 war with [[Slobodan Milošević]]'s regime, though Israel has refused to recognise Kosovo's independence so far.{{cite news |last=Mizroch |first=Amir |coauthors= |title=Israel won't recognize Kosovo, for now |work= |pages= |language= |publisher=Jerusalem Post |date=2008-02-19 |url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1203343699593&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110916154608/http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1203343699593&pagename=JPost%2FJPArticle%2FShowFull |archivedate=2011-09-16 |df= }} ==See also== *[[Judaism]] *[[Kosovo-Israel relations]] ==Notes and references== '''Notes:''' {| style="margin-left:13px; line-height:150%" |align="right" valign="top"|a.   |{{Note|a}} The original Turkish-language copy of the census is stored in Istanbul's archives. However, in 1972 the Sarajevo Institute of Middle Eastern Studies translated the census and published an analysis of it Kovačević Mr. Ešref, Handžić A., Hadžibegović H. Oblast Brankovića - Opširni katastarski popis iz 1455., Orijentalni institut, Sarajevo 1972. Subsequently, others have covered the subject as well such as Vukanović Tatomir, Srbi na Kosovu, Vranje, 1986. |} '''References:''' {{reflist}} {{Ethnic groups in Kosovo}} {{History of the Jews in Europe}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Kosovo|Jewish]] [[Category:History of Kosovo|Jewish]] [[Category:History of the Jews in Europe|Kosovo]] [[Category:Jewish history by country|Kosovo]] [[Category:Jews and Judaism in Yugoslavia|Kosovo]]

revision.comment: /* top */clean up, replaced: Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons → [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]], "Tier 2 Watchlist" →... using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
clean up spacing around commas, replaced: ,G → , G, ,K → , K, ,T → , T, ,U → , U using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Indira Priyadarshini Vriksha Mitra Awards''' or IPVM Awards are given by [[Ministry of Environment and Forests (India)|Ministry of Environment and Forests]]<ref>[http://moef.nic.in/modules/fellowships-and-awards/awards/?f=2#2 Ministry of Environment& Forests, Government of India]</ref> of [[Government of India]] to individuals and institutions who have done pioneering and exemplary work in the field of afforestation and wasteland development. A cash award of Rupees Two lakh fifty thousand is presented to individuals/institutions in seven categories. It was instituted in 1986 and were given annually. Initially IPVM awards were given in twelve categories till 2006. But as per 2012 notification of Ministry of Environment and Forests Seven Categories are approved for IPVM Awards.
==Criteria== As per the [[Press Information Bureau]] of Government of India the activities deciding the awards are ''establishing decentralized nurseries; tree planting on wastelands/farm land; awareness- raising, motivations and extension work; involving the rural poor/ tribal / cooperatives in Afforestation and tree planting; setting up grass-roots level institutions like the Tree Growers’ Cooperative; and social fencing of community woodlots and pasture lands''.<ref name="test1">[http://pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=54251 Press Information Bureau- Press Release]</ref>
==Categories== # Individual-Forest Officers # Individual-Other than Forest Officers # Institutions/Organisations under Government # Joint Forest Management Committees ( six awards region-wise) # Non-profit making Voluntary Organisations (NGOs) # Corporate Sector (Private/Public Sector Agencies) # Eco-Clubs at School Level (covered under National Green Corps Programme of the Ministry of Environment and Forests)
==Recipients==

revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=February 2011}} [[Image:Nevadacave1.jpeg|right|200px|thumb|Jack Lee Harelson looting Elephant Mountain Cave in the Black Rock Desert]] '''Jack Lee Harelson''' (1940 - December 14, 2012) was an [[United States|American]] [[insurance agent]], best known for [[desecration|desecrating]] and looting a [[Northern Paiute|Paiute]] Indian burial site in the [[Black Rock Desert]] of [[Nevada]].
==Biography==
Jack Lee Harelson was an insurance agent in [[Grants Pass, Oregon]]. In 1995, one of his former business partners in an [[opal]] mine tipped off police that Harelson had been looting Amerindian sites. In exchange for immunity from prosecution, Harelson's ex-wife Pamela Ralph led police investigators to an Elephant Mountain<ref> {{cite gnis |type=summit |id=847170 |name=Elephant Mountain |accessdate=17 April 2010 }}</ref> Cave in the Black Rock Desert in Nevada. She stated that she and Harelson had dug and collected American Indian treasures in the early 1980s. She had photographs of the cave that had significantly grown after three years of digging. Harelson had built a wall to hide a dirt pile. Digging had totally destroyed the site, which had included various artifacts, including those from the [[Northern Paiute|Paiute]] tribe.
[[Oregon State Police]] recovered over 2,000 artifacts from Harelson's home in Grants Pass, including 10,000-year-old sandals. In Harelson's garden, police found two [[decapitation|headless bodies]] of Paiute children wrapped in plastic garbage bags. These bodies were historical, maybe 2,000 years old. The heads were not found. Ralph said that bodies were intact when they were found in two large baskets.
The state prosecutor charged Harelson for looting and desecrating the site. He was charged with [[theft|aggravated theft]], [[abuse of corpse]]s, tampering with [[evidence]] and possessing illegal [[gambling]] devices. The main witness in the case was Pamela Ralph, but his old business partners also testified.
Harelson admitted only to digging a "test hole" and removing some artifacts and said that he had intended to attract interest of archaeologists and to hand the artifacts over later. He stated that he had reported significant [[paleontology|paleontological]] finds to the [[Nevada State Museum, Carson City|Nevada State Museum]]. The museum acknowledged that.
Harelson's defense claimed he was a collector who had bought the Amerindian artifacts and was not involved with dealing them. The defense tried to have charges dismissed on the grounds that the [[statute of limitations]] had expired. The prosecutor successfully argued that continued possession of the items constituted continuation of the crime. Harelson was found guilty of abuse of a corpse and possession of state property. He received a fine of $20,000 and spent 30 days in jail.
Harelson lost his insurance agent's licence and began an online business, called Jack's Outback, selling opals and things like [[petroglyph]] reproductions and artifact display cases. According to a later police report, he also continued to deal in [[illegal antiquities]] and solicited excavation of sites in Oregon and Nevada.
On December 6, 2002, a federal administrative law judge in Oregon fined Harelson $2.5 million for destruction of archaeological resources.<ref> {{cite journal |title=Big Time Fine For Cave Looter |last=Powell |first=Eric A. |magazine=[[Archaeology (magazine)|Archaeology]] |volume=56 |issue=2 |date=March–April 2003 |url=http://www.archaeology.org/online/features/nevadacave/ |accessdate=17 April 2010}}</ref> Further investigation unearthed two skulls that may have belonged to the two Paiute corpses. Harelson claimed that he had no money and accused the government of turning him into a scapegoat. Behind the scenes, police investigation about his antique dealings continued.
In January 2003, authorities discovered that Harelson intended to kill police sergeant Walt Markee, who had searched Harelson's home, County Judge Loyd O'Neal, who had presided over the 1996 trial, Harelson's ex-wife and two former business partners. An undercover policeman approached Harelson in the role of a [[hitman]] willing to carry out the murders for a price. Harelson paid the policeman $10,000 in the form of opals after the policeman showed Harelson a fabricated photograph of the corpse of one of the intended murder victims. The transaction was videotaped, and police later arrested Harelson in his home with the help of a [[SWAT]] team.
In 2004, the [[Government of Oregon|State of Oregon]] charged Harelson with multiple counts of [[conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]] to commit aggravated [[murder]] and [[gun control|illegal possession of a firearm]]. He was sent to jail without [[bail]] to await sentencing. Later in 2004, Harelson's bid to overturn the $2.5 million fine failed.<ref>{{cite news |title=$2.5 Million Cave Looting Fine Stands |date=24 April 2004 |newspaper=[[Press-Telegram (Long Beach)|Press-Telegram]] |location=[[Long Beach, California]] |page=A18 }}</ref> As of October, 2009, Harelson was serving a 10-year prison sentence in the [[Eastern Oregon Correctional Institution]] in [[Pendleton, Oregon]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Oregon effort aims to protect tribal remains |last=Bella |first=Rick |newspaper=[[The Oregonian]] |date=12 October 2009 |location=[[Portland, Oregon]] |ISSN=8750-1317 |url=http://www.oregonlive.com/clackamascounty/index.ssf/2009/10/clackamas_county_state_agencie.html |accessdate=17 April 2010}}</ref> Harelson died on December 14, 2012 in the Oregon State Penitentiary in Salem.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2254008/Archaeologist-looted-Indian-graves-offered-opals-murder-hire-plot-dies-prison.html |title=Archaeologist who looted Indian graves and offered opals in murder-for-hire plot dies in prison | Mail Online |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2012-12-28 |accessdate=2013-06-19}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{cite web |title=Cave Looter Solicits Murder |last=Powell |first=Eric A. |date=27 January 2003 |work=[[Archaeology (magazine)|Archaeology]] |url=http://www.archaeology.org/online/features/nevadacave/ |accessdate=17 April 2010}} * {{cite news |title=The Killing Bones |last=Barcott |first=Bruce |magazine=[[Outside (magazine)|Outside]] |date=October 2004 |url=http://outside.away.com/outside/features/200410/native_america_artifacts_1.html |accessdate=17 April 2010}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Harelson, Jack Lee}} [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:American criminals]] [[Category:People convicted of soliciting murder]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of Oregon]] [[Category:Archaeological theft]] [[Category:American people convicted of theft]] [[Category:People from Grants Pass, Oregon]]

[[File:Menumbuk padi 080815 2320 srna.JPG|thumb|300px|Pestling rice in the traditional fashion at Sirnarasa village]] The '''Kasepuhan''' or '''Kasepuhan Banten Kidul''' are a traditional [[Sundanese people|Sundanese]] community of approximately 5,300 people, who live in the southern part of [[Gunung Halimun National Park]], in the [[Indonesia]]n province of [[West Java]]. Gunung Halimun National Park is located within the borders of the [[Sukabumi Regency]], [[Bogor]] and southern [[Banten]] province. The Kasepuhan is called "Kasepuhan Banten Kidul" (Kasepuhan of Southern Banten), their main village is Ciptagelar in the Cisolok subdistrict (''kecamatan'') in the western part of the [[Sukabumi Regency]]. The current head of the community, Abah Ugih, inherited the position of leader when his father, Abah Anom, died at the age of 54.<ref>J. Adiguna, '[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2008/08/11/living-harmony-with-nature.html-3 Living in harmony with the nature'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514223326/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2008/08/11/living-harmony-with-nature.html-3 |date=2014-05-14 }}, ''The Jakarta Post'', 11 August 2008.</ref>
==Etymology== The word ''kasepuhan'' is formed on ''sepuh'', which means "old" in the [[Sundanese language]]. It refers to a way of living based on ancestral traditions and eventually, to the local community who lives according to these traditions.
==History and tradition== According to oral information, the Kasepuhan have lived in this area (''Banten Kidul'', or ''south Banten'') since 1368. The ancestors of the Kasepuhan are said to have lived in the area of Bogor, east of Gunung Halimun. At that time, their ancestors were part of a kingdom that encompassed the province of West Java and Banten.
The people of the Kasepuhan claim they are linked with the [[Baduy people|Baduy]], another traditional group in West Java. The main belief system of Kasepuhan people is [[Sunda Wiwitan]]. Nowadays, the Kasepuhan are influenced by [[Islam]]. However they do not strictly follow all rules of Islam but, rather, combine their beliefs with [[animism]] and [[Sundanese (people)|Sundanese]] traditions. Just as their ancestors, they have combined several traditions and religions with their own Kasepuhan tradition; that is, they are influenced by Islam, Sundanese traditions, Pajajaran traditions and thus Hinduism and also animism.
The main ritual of Kasepuhan community is ''[[Seren Taun]]'', or rice harvest thanksgiving as well as marking the new agriculture year in [[Sundanese people|Sundanese]] tradition. Seren Taun festival also celebrated by other Sundanese traditional communities in other areas such as Sundanese community in Cigugur [[Kuningan]].<ref>[http://travel.kompas.com/read/2011/01/23/09340353/Hari.Ini.Puncak.Seren.Taun.di.Bogor Seren Taun Bogor]</ref>
The Kasepuhan history existed since 1368 (note: the years allowed to write down) their believe before that time also they still have story, but enough to lets other peoples known only from that time. the areas of the kingdom called " Banten Kidul" its a territories before the government age, and now this Banten Kidul area on three sub district areas ( Lebak, Bogor and Sukabumi) The peoples in Kasepuhan still living in the tradition and ancient cultures role of custom, following what the ancestor said for their life and living on rice plantation. the rice they have to plan is only rice seed from the ancestor ( data 2014: there are 167 original varieties) planting till today, and more than 300 new varieties from natural mixing on the rice field.
By far the most important way of subsistence for the Kasepuhan is agriculture, which can split into two categories: ' Huma'' (Dry rice cultivation), ''Sawah'' (wet rice cultivation). the Dry system rice plantation is the original way plantation from the ancestor, and since the Dutch time then they have wets system rice plantation called "Sawah".
About 85% of Kasepuhan agricultural land is ''sawah'', 10% consists of ''ladang'', and 5% ''kebun''. There is a strong emphasis on eco-friendly techniques of farming within the community.and the other land is Forestry, living in the forest also message from the ancestor to keep the tradition safely, make distance with the city from outside influence, they have three categories forestry for : Leuweung Tutupan (forbidden forest), Leuweung Titipan (forbidden forest) and Leuweung Garapan ( the plots forest), and the peoples living in the plots lands <ref>Sri Wahyuni, '[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2008/10/25/painting-campaign-calls-justice-climate-change.html Painting campaign calls for justice on climate change'], ''The Jakarta Post'', 25 October 2008.</ref>
== References == Bas Bolman (2006). [http://library.wur.nl/way/bestanden/clc/1843354.pdf ''Wet rice cultivation in Indonesia - A comparative research on differences in modernisation trends.''] Major Thesis, Wageningen University.
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}

{{one source|date=December 2015}} An [[endangered language]] is a [[language]] that is at a risk of falling out of use, generally because it has few surviving speakers. If it loses all of its native speakers, it becomes an [[extinct language]]. [[UNESCO]] defines [[Endangered language#UNESCO definitions|four levels of language endangerment]] between "safe" (not endangered) and "extinct":<ref name="UNESCO"> {{cite book |year=2010 |editor-last=Moseley |editor-first=Christopher |title=Atlas of the World’s Languages in Danger |url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/culture/themes/endangered-languages/atlas-of-languages-in-danger/ |series=Memory of Peoples |edition=3rd |location=Paris |publisher=UNESCO Publishing |isbn=978-92-3-104096-2 |access-date=2015-04-11 }}</ref> * Vulnerable * Definitely endangered * Severely endangered * Critically endangered
==India== {{Main|Languages of India}} The following table lists the 191 languages of India that are classified as vulnerable or endangered. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:auto; page.title: List of fan conventions by date of founding

revision.text:
The '''list of modern [[fan conventions]]''' for various genres of entertainment extends to the first conventions held in the 1930s.
Some fan historians claim that the 1936 Philadelphia Science Fiction Conference, a.k.a. [[Philcon]], was the first science fiction convention ever held. Others, such as [[Fred Patten]] and [[Rob Hansen]], make this claim for the January 1937 event in [[Leeds]], [[England]],<ref>Mike Glyer. [http://www.fiawol.org.uk/fanstuff/THEN%20Archive/1937conFirst.htm "THE FIRST EVER CONVENTION,"] ''The Story So Far'' (Worldcon, 1987).</ref> organized by the Leeds Science Fiction League, which was specifically organised as a conference, with a program and speakers. Out of this came the first incarnation of the [[British Science Fiction Association]].
While a few conventions were created in various parts of the world within the period between 1935-1960, the number of convention establishments increased slightly in the 1960s and then increased dramatically in the 1970s, with many of the largest conventions in the modern era being established during the latter decade. Impeti for further establishment of local fan conventions include:
* The return of superhero characters and franchises during the [[Silver Age of Comic Books]] (1956-1970) * science fiction adaptations for television serials (e.g., ''[[Star Trek]]'') in the 1960s-1970s * the growth of role-playing (in the 1970s and 1980s) as a genre of tabletop, live-action and eventually video/computer gaming, which not only inspired roleplay of favorite characters in full-body costumes but also inspired existing franchises to adapt their themes for said methods of gaming * the growth in home taping (starting with VHS in the late 1970s) of television broadcasts, including popular serials. * the growth of computerized communication, including the Internet and Internet-dependent applications in the 1980s and 1990s.
{{TOC right}}
==1930s== * [[Philcon]] (1936) * [[Worldcon]] (1939)
==1940s== * [[Boskone (convention)|Boskone]] (1941) * [[Eastercon]] (1948) * [[Westercon]] (1948)

The '''Microsoft licensing corruption scandal''' is an ongoing political scandal and criminal investigation in Romania, involving large bribes paid to [[Romanian government]] members in exchange for approving increases in license fees for [[Microsoft]] products.
Nine government ministers have been charged by the [[National Anticorruption Directorate]],<ref name="DNA26sep2014">[[National Anticorruption Directorate]], [http://www.pna.ro/comunicat.xhtml?id=5309 Comunicat Nr. 1342/VIII/3], 26 September 2014</ref> belonging to the [[First Năstase cabinet|Năstase]], [[Tăriceanu I Cabinet|Tăriceanu]] and [[Boc Cabinets]]. The bribes were estimated at more than $50 million.<ref>[http://www.gandul.info/stiri/claudiu-florica-personajul-cheie-dosarul-fraudelor-it-printre-cei-identificati-dna-reteaua-bittner-niro-plus-vedeti-articol-fotografie-arhiva-florica-guvern-13357669 Cine este Claudiu Florică, personajul cheie din DOSARUL FRAUDELOR din IT"], September 30, 2014</ref>
Apart from Microsoft, this scandal involved several major multinational corporations, including [[Fujitsu-Siemens]], [[IBM]], [[Compaq]], [[Hewlett-Packard]], [[S&T (company)|S&T]] and local software companies like SIVECO and [[Softwin]].<ref>[http://economie.hotnews.ro/stiri-telecom-18222395-autodenunt-dosarul-microsoft-cum-dat-spaga-guvernantilor-marilor-corporatii-mai-bine-13-ani.htm "Autodenunt in dosarul Microsoft: Cum le-am dat eu spaga guvernantilor si marilor corporatii IT mai bine de 13 ani"], ''Hotnews'', October 2, 2014</ref> ==Persons involved in scandal== According to [[Gheorghe Ștefan (politician)|Gheorghe Ștefan]] (a.k.a. "Pinalti"), more than 100 persons are involved in the corruption scandal,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.antena3.ro/politica/dezvaluiri-din-dosarul-microsoft-pinalti-peste-100-de-persoane-implicate-printre-ei-si-ministri-voi-281307.html |title=DEZVĂLUIRI din Dosarul Microsoft. Pinalti: Peste 100 de persoane implicate, printre ei şi MINIŞTRI. Voi da toate sumele şi numele |work=Antena 3 |date=28 January 2015 |last=Z. |first=M. |language=Romanian}}</ref> among them nine former ministers<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mediafax.ro/social/dna-cere-urmarirea-penala-a-noua-fosti-ministri-in-cazul-licentelor-microsoft-persoane-din-guvern-si-ministere-au-pretins-comisioane-de-20-milioane-de-dolari-reactii-ale-fostilor-ministri-13351996 |title=DNA cere URMĂRIREA PENALĂ a nouă foşti miniştri, în cazul licenţelor Microsoft. Persoane din Guvern şi ministere au pretins comisioane de 20 milioane de dolari. REACŢII ale foştilor miniştri |work=Mediafax.ro |date=26 September 2014 |last=Ispas |first=Livia |language=Romanian}}</ref> and prominent businessmen. * [[Elena Udrea]], President of the [[People's Movement Party]] (2014–15) and Minister of Tourism (2008–12) * [[Adriean Videanu]], Minister of Economy (2008–10) and Mayor of [[Bucharest]] (2005–08) * [[Ecaterina Andronescu]], Minister of Education (2000–03, 2008–09, 2012) * {{ill|Valerian Vreme|ro}}, former Minister of Communications * {{ill|Șerban Mihăilescu|ro}}, PSD senator * [[Dan Nica]], Minister of Communications (2000–04, 2012) and Minister of the Interior (2009) * [[Silvia Adriana Țicău|Adriana Țicău]], PSD MEP * [[Gabriel Sandu]], Minister of Communications (2008–10) * [[Daniel Funeriu]], Minister of Education (2009–12) * [[Alexandru Athanasiu]], PSD MEP and Acting [[Prime Minister of Romania]] (1999) * [[Mihai Tănăsescu]], Member of the [[Trilateral Commission]] * {{Interlanguage link multi|Dorin Cocoș|ro}}, businessman and former spouse of Elena Udrea * [[Gheorghe Ștefan (politician)|Gheorghe Ștefan]], former Mayor of [[Piatra Neamț]] * Dumitru Nicolae, businessman
==Sentences== On 24 March 2016, Dorin Cocoș was sentenced to 2 years imprisonment for influence peddling and money laundering, and to an [[asset forfeiture]] of €3 million. Gabriel Sandu was sentenced to 2 years imprisonment for bribery and money laundering, and to an asset forfeiture of over €2 million. Gheorghe Ștefan was sentenced to 3 years imprisonment for influence peddling and to an asset forfeiture of €3 million. Dumitru Nicolae was convicted to 1 and a half years [[suspended sentence]], €1 million forfeiture and 90 days community service.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mediafax.ro/politic/dosarul-microsoft-dorin-cocos-si-fostul-ministru-gabriel-sandu-cate-doi-ani-de-inchisoare-gheorghe-stefan-a-primit-trei-ani-15145773|title=DOSARUL MICROSOFT: Dorin Cocoş şi fostul ministru Gabriel Sandu, câte doi ani de închisoare. Gheorghe Ştefan a primit trei ani|newspaper=Mediafax|date=24 March 2016|accessdate=24 March 2016|language=Romanian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.digi24.ro/Stiri/Digi24/Actualitate/Justitie/Sentinta+in+dosarul+Microsoft|title=Sentință în dosarul Microsoft. Pedepse cu executare și confiscarea a 10 milioane de euro|newspaper=Digi24|date=24 March 2016|accessdate=24 March 2016|language=Romanian}}</ref> The sentences are not final and can be appealed.
On 3 October 2016, Dorin Cocoș was sentenced to 2 years 4 months imprisonment for influence peddling and money laundering, and to an [[asset forfeiture]] of €9 million. Gabriel Sandu was sentenced to 3 years imprisonment for bribery and money laundering, and to an asset forfeiture of over €2 million. Gheorghe Ștefan was sentenced to 6 years imprisonment for influence peddling and to an asset forfeiture of over €3 million. Nicolae Dumitru was convicted to 2 years 4 months imprisonment, $2,050,000 and €1 million forfeiture.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mediafax.ro/social/condamnari-definitive-dosarul-microsoft-dumitru-nicolae-niro-dorin-cocos-condamnati-cate-2-ani-4-luni-inchisoare-gabriel-sandu-3-ani-gheorghe-stefan-6-ani-gheorghe-stefan-ma-consider-vinovat-video-15757850|title=Condamnări definitive în Dosarul "Microsoft". Dumitru Nicolae (Niro) şi Dorin Cocoş, condamnaţi la câte 2 ani şi 4 luni închisoare, Gabriel Sandu - 3 ani, Gheorghe Ştefan - 6 ani. Gheorghe Ştefan: "Mă consider vinovat"|newspaper=Mediafax|date=3 October 2016|accessdate=4 October 2016|language=Romanian}}</ref> These sentences are final.
==See also== * [[List of corruption scandals in Romania]]
